channel.title: BBC News - Asia
channel.description: The latest stories from the Asia section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Pakistan bomb victims' burials begin
item.description: Shia Muslims in the Pakistani city of Quetta begin to bury victims of Saturday's bomb attack, ending a protest at official inaction.

item.title: China condemns US hacking report
item.description: China's military says a report linking it to prolific hacking of US targets is flawed, as the US says it has repeatedly raised concerns about cyber theft with Beijing.

item.title: Lost Antarctic penguin found in NZ
item.description: A royal penguin is being cared for at a Wellington Zoo after washing up on the coast of New Zealand, 2,000km (1,240 miles) from its Antarctic home.

item.title: Japan posts record trade deficit
item.description: Japan's monthly trade deficit hits a record in January after its recent monetary policy stance weakened its currency sharply.

item.title: Two Tibetan youths 'self-immolate'
item.description: Two Tibetan youths, aged 17 and 18, have burned themselves to death in protest in western China, reports from activists and Tibetan exiles say.

item.title: Activists clash with Japan whalers
item.description: Japan's whaling fleet clashes with anti-whaling group Sea Shepherd in the Southern Ocean, with the activists saying their boat was rammed.

item.title: 'Action needed' on football fixing
item.description: Football officials say countries and organisations must do more to tackle corruption, at a conference on match-fixing in Kuala Lumpur.

item.title: Cameron marks Amritsar massacre
item.description: David Cameron becomes the first serving UK prime minister to pay his respects at the scene of one of the bloodiest massacres in British history.

item.title: Sporadic violence marks India strike
item.description: Sporadic violence marks the beginning of a two-day strike called by India's trade unions in protest against economic reforms

item.title: S Lanka army 'killed boy in custody'
item.description: Photographs emerge said to show the 12-year-old son of a Tamil rebel leader alive and well in custody less than two hours before he was shot dead.

item.title: North Korea threatens South Korea
item.description: North Korea has been criticised for remarks about the "final destruction" of South Korea made during a UN debate on disarmament

item.title: Afghanistan civilian casualties fall
item.description: The number of civilian casualties in Afghanistan has fallen for the first time in six years, a new UN report says, with 2,754 losing their lives.

item.title: VIDEO: Filipino workers speak of abuse
item.description: Many people faced with limited job options and grinding poverty in the Philippines have decided to look for work overseas - but they risk being forced into slave labour.

item.title: VIDEO: BBC reporter detained amid China hacking
item.description: A secretive branch of China's military is most likely one of the world's "most prolific cyber espionage groups", a US cyber security firm has said.

item.title: VIDEO: 'No one in China knew about hacking'
item.description: A computer security company based in the US says the Chinese military is behind a series of high-level cyber-hacking attacks.

item.title: VIDEO: Slum children flock to free school
item.description: A shopkeeper in New Delhi runs an improvised school under a railway bridge in New Delhi to help raise children from nearby slums out of poverty.

item.title: VIDEO: Japan rock star's 'quiet UK life'
item.description: Six months ago, the Gangnam Style star Psy remained largely unknown outside of his native Korea, but today his video has been viewed more than a billion times on YouTube.

item.title: VIDEO: Fall in Afghan civilian casualties
item.description: The number of civilian casualties in Afghanistan has fallen for the first time in six years, a UN report says.

item.title: VIDEO: 'Proud my son died for his beliefs'
item.description: Following the deaths of 16 insurgents in Thailand in a failed attack on a Thai marine base, the BBC's Jonathan Head speaks to some of the insurgents' bereaved families.

item.title: VIDEO: Families' fury over Pakistan blast
item.description: Quetta blast victims' fury at army 'failure' to tackle ethnic violence

item.title: Beatles help India traffic campaign
item.description: The police in the eastern Indian city of Calcutta is using the picture on the cover of the iconic Beatles album Abbey Road in a campaign to enforce road safety.

item.title: Gold bars for tsunami-hit Japan port
item.description: People in a small Japanese fishing port devastated by the 2011 tsunami have been receiving gold bars in the post from an anonymous benefactor.

item.title: Fields revels in historic hat-trick
item.description: Australia captain Jodie Fields says victory over West Indies in the Women's World Cup final completed a "great piece of history".

item.title: China media: Hacking denial
item.description: Media and experts back China's denial of allegations that one of its military units is behind prolific cyber attacks against US firms.

item.title: China bans footballers for fixing
item.description: China's football authorities ban 33 players and officials for life and strip Shanghai Shenhua of league title after investigation.

item.title: Kidnap 'kingpin' sent back to China
item.description: A Chinese national suspected of heading a kidnapping ring targeting Chinese citizens in Venezuela is brought back to China, officials say.

item.title: AirAsia plans Indian budget carrier
item.description: Asia's largest low-cost carrier, AirAsia, plans to launch an Indian budget airline with India's Tata and a third investor, Telestra Tradeplace.

item.title: India detentions for rape and murder
item.description: Police in India detain three men in the state of Maharashtra in connection with the rape and murder of three sisters aged between six and 11.

item.title: Bandit gang hangings delayed again
item.description: India's Supreme Court puts on hold "until further orders" the execution of four men convicted of being associates of notorious bandit Veerappan.

item.title: Two charged in PNG 'sorcery' killing
item.description: Two people are charged in Papua New Guinea with burning alive a woman they accused of sorcery, officials say.

item.title: Guam knife attack toll rises
item.description: The death toll from an attack in Guam rose to three after a Japanese man mown down by a car died of his injuries, officials say.

item.title: Three charged in rhino horn ring
item.description: Three people are arrested in the US and accused of a conspiring to smuggle endangered black rhinoceros horns to China, prosecutors say.

item.title: Bangladesh protests spark law change
item.description: Bangladesh alters a law to allow the state to appeal against the life sentence of an Islamist party leader, after protesters called for his execution.

item.title: Sri Lanka group seeks halal boycott
item.description: A hardline Sinhalese Buddhist group in Sri Lanka calls for the abolition of the Muslim halal system of certifying foods and other goods.

item.title: Anger over Pakistan blast 'failures'
item.description: The governor of Pakistan's Balochistan province denounces intelligence failures as the death toll in a sectarian bombing in Quetta rises to 81.

item.title: BHP Billiton boss Kloppers to retire

item.description: Damning reports put Australia's athletes in the spotlight
